text: This episode is brought to you by Wix.

What’s up guys, Jared here and today we’re
talking about the surprising, head-scratcher
of a season finale for South Park Season 22.

The final two episodes, Unfulfilled and Bike
Parade, are the first and probably only time

you’ll see the show quoting the Communist
Manifesto

“And from their very essence, the oppressed
worker will eventually strike back at those
capitalists who control the means of production.
We have nothing to lose but our chains”

So, have Matt Stone and Trey Parker turned
against Big business like the denizens of
South Park?

Well Let’s find out in this Wisecrack Edition
on the finale of South Park season 22.
And obviously- spoilers ahead.

But, before we get started, wanna give a shoutout
to our sponsors over at Wix.

Wix is the easiest way to create awesome,
professional websites.

As I mentioned in an earlier video, I’m
trying to make some side-money doing voiceover

work, so lemme show you how I created my professional
site with voice samples.

So here wanna create a website for MYSELF,
and you can see they have a whole bunch of

options so a business, nah, designer, photography,
no I want to build a portfolio & CV and yeah,
I pretty much suck at computers.

Turns out, there’s already a template for
voice over artists.

I picked a style and within minutes I was
dragging and dropping my audio files and BAM-
done.

Now I have a site I can send to potential
clients and it looks GOOD.

So, if you’re looking to up your game before
2019, go to wix.com/wisecrack or click the

link in the description to start making your
FREE website today.
And now back to the show.

All right guys,
First, a quick recap:

In Unfulfilled, an Amazon fulfillment center
comes to town,

where a workplace accident crushes a guy named
Josh,

and his surviving organs are crammed in a
box.

“My organs have been compacted so if the
box opens I spill out and die.”

His boxed organs agitate for working class
rebellion, causing Amazon’s employees go
on strike.

Meanwhile, the kids want to flex at the bike
parade to get girls but can’t deck out their
bikes without their amazon packages.

Then, in Bike Parade, mall workers try to
break the strike,

and anyone willing to help Jeff Bezos gets
their orders fulfilled.

Once Kenny’s newfound socialist beliefs
ruin their plans for the parade,
“You’re not going to do the bike parade?”
“Why not?!”
“*Kenny Muffling*” “Commodity fetishism?”
the boys try to get it cancelled.

Meanwhile, Randy’s struggling weed business
gets a boost from everyone jonesing for their
Amazon packages.

Stoned and content, the citizens of South
Park realize they’d rather keep their ‘tegridy
than suck a Bezosian dick.

To figure out what Matt and Trey are saying
about the economy, we have to start with this
intro montage of the Amazon fulfillment center
“You load sixteen tons, whaddya get?
Another day older and deeper in debt.”

The song playing, “16 Tons,” has a million
covers, but the original was written by Merle
Travis about the life of coal miners in Kentucky.

The song highlights the troubles of living
in company towns - a common practice that
faded out in the middle of the 20th century.

Company towns were places where a single employer
dominated economic life.

Sometimes, companies would open a factory
and literally build the housing, schools and
hospitals for its employees.

But more importantly, companies would pay
their employees with their own version of

vBucks that were only redeemable at company-owned
businesses.

What resulted was, functionally, slavery with
extra steps.

Workers could never move because all their
savings were useless outside the company store.

“St. Peter don't you call me 'cause I can't
go.
I owe my soul to the company store.”

and running up a debt at the company store
would further obligate you to stay until you
paid it off

So, is South Park calling Amazon a modern-day
company town?

Sure, Amazon isn’t paying people in PrimeBucks,
and there’s no debt slavery either.

But Amazon does seem to infiltrate every aspect
of South Park life
"Whatcha got on tap?"
"Amazon, Amazon lite, and Amazon IPA"

But especially in episode 10, we see that
the primary motivation for working at Amazon
is to buy your kids more stuff from Amazon.

Mr. Stotch’s motivation for going back to
work

is to have his orders fulfilled for Butter’s
Peacock bike.

And like the Merle Travis song, your paycheck
has a way of ending up right back into the
company store.

“Loading up forklifts, getting paper cuts
from boxes, and for what?

A measly paycheck that just barely covers
our online purchases”

And while the people of South Park, in theory,
could take their real dollars to some other

business, the show hints at how big business
coming to town can create a not-so-free market.

When the boys try to find supplies to protest
the bike parade, all the other businesses
have gone under.

“yeah well when the Amazon fulfillment center
opened, everything else went out of business”

A similar dynamic happens not just with Amazon,
but Walmart, where low-paid employees only
had enough money to shop at Walmart,
“You get a discount working here.
That means the bargains are even better”

ensuring the destruction of local businesses,
driving more people to work at Walmart, and,
well, you get it.

This problem seems encapsulated by Jeff Bezos’
term - consumer-worker
“Before there was war between classes.
Customers and workers at odds.

All I've done is create the new class: the
consumer-worker.”

Doubling down on the same sense of resignation
that pervades the season, people support a

company they don’t even like because they
feel they don’t have any choice.
“I want to quit working for Amazon.

I want to join my friends in striking, but
I know that you have to have your stuff to
be happy”

This hopelessness is also a nod to the real-life
bidding war to host Amazon’s 2nd headquarters.

As you probably know, Matt Stone and Trey
Parker are libertarians, and the last two

episodes seem to further a criticism of government
involvement in the market.

Specifically, the way “business-minded”
politicians get in bed with giant corporations

to create a grotesque version of the free
market.

If the workers are selling their soul to the
company store, towns and governments are selling
their soul to Jeff Bezos’ throbbing skull.
“We had a deal mayor.

You told me this town would be the perfect
place for one of our fulfillment centers.”

The creation of jobs holds local governments
functionally hostage to their whims.

“Perhaps you should no longer be a prime
member”

And while yes, Amazon fulfillment centers
are a good example, you could easily replace

Amazon with any sports stadium or manufacturer
seeking tax breaks that force local governments

into a race to the bottom in deals that leave
them another day older and deeper in debt.

In short, the show criticizes the imbalance
of power between companies like Amazon
and local communities and their workers.

Amazon dehumanizes the strikers when their
status is downgraded from Prime to
“Amazon USDA Choice,”
as in, meat.

And Josh’s humanity is exactly what gets
him killed, when Amazon labels his death
“Human Error”
So, is there any escape from this nightmare?
Well.
Sort of.

As Randy bemoans the strike messing up his
business, customers start lining up at his
door.
"Hey are you selling weed?"
"Uh.

Yeah" "My wife is going nuts not getting her
packages and I told her I’d find her some
kush”

Local competition soon forces Randy to optimize
convenience by delivering weed to people’s
homes, starting an app
“We have an app now!”
and even a membership program.

“We're just making sure folks are aware
of our new rewards program”
In other words, he becomes the Amazon of weed.
So, what is South Park trying to say here?

Well on the one hand, that ‘tegridy in business
usually doesn’t mean shit.

Going back all the way to the Gnomes episode
of season 2, we see that small business can

be just as evil and exploitative as big bad
Harbucks.

“We’re just using those boys for our benefit,
they have no idea what they’re saying”

“But kids are great to get people on our
side”

And 20 years later, South Park’s message
hasn’t deviated much.
“You know what they got?

They got these E-scooters now-a-days" "You
mean the things that almost killed us all
on Halloween?
Yeah, I member."

"What if, we use the e-scooters to get weed
directly to the customers?"

Those things that were once devoid of tegridy
are now the vehicles with which he sells ‘Tegridy
weed.’
And of course, the episode ends with this.
“Tegridy weed.

Coming soon to a giant online retailer near
you.”

Complain all you want about Harbucks, Walmart
or Amazon, they’re just going to be replaced
by something equally sinister.

Because at the end of the day, if I don’t
get my f*cking gamecube adapter for Smash

Bros by Wednesday, I swear to god I’m burning
f*cker to the ground.

What’s interesting is that the strikers
and our marxist-in-a-box are cast in a pretty
sympathetic light.
Sure, Jeff Bezos has this to say about Josh,

“See how the box ridicules commercialism
in order to feel better about itself?”

A sentiment of resentment echoed by the boys
as they try to cancel the bike parade to obscure
their own failure.

“We're never gonna win the bike parade,
but if we get it canceled then everybody loses.”

But, as with the rest of the season, the message
seems to be resignation.

Strikers are encouraged to cross picket lines
to appease their materialistic children.

“Now there's kids out there who have better
bikes than me because you won't get off your
ass and work DAD.”

And Josh gets ripped open by a mob of gift-hungry
kids.
Jeff Bezos, as Josh says, makes

“Too many useful things resulting in too
many useless people.”
but it seems we can’t resist

“You need your Amazon prime shows and your
music, and your books and your things delivered
to your door like little presents to yourself.”

In true South Park fashion, our only savior
is a fake one- a fake claim to authenticity

in the form of “tegridy” that ends up
just being repackaged and sold by a huge online
retailer.

Even though it’s a functional Amazon, we’re
reminded

“you don’t want to be elite, cuz elites
got no tegrity”

Even our anti-consumerist dissent is just
a regular part of the business cycle.

It’s not that integrity saved South Park,
but the cynical interest of Randy

“Only I can really package tegrity, I got
more money now cause of tegrity that’s cause
I figured out how to get tregrity to everyone”

What was once supposed to be a counter-cultural
rejection of modern life becomes a symbol
for the commodification of dissent.

The bike parade, which was once a pawn in
Jeff Bezos’ scheme to break the strike,

is now sponsored by ‘tegridy weed, city
wok and La Taco.

South Park too seems content to bask in cynical
‘tegridy.

As the boys try to cancel the bike parade,
it becomes clear that the parade is a metaphor
for the show and its marketing campaign: #cancelsouthpark.
"We demand you cancel the bike parade."

"It is nihilistic and out of touch with progressive
thinking."

"How come everything out there is getting
canceled but when it comes to us we just can’t
do it?"

“I mean are we supposed to just keep going…
just go on… making total asses of ourselves?"

Just as South Park was promoting itself with
a half-serious critique of itself, the show

is content to continue basking in the business
of selling television ads with a half-serious
critique of consumerism.

"Now, if you really want to stick it to the
man, I recommend you try Wix.

There’s no better way to discover the true
joy of unalienated labor than by designing
your own website.

A spectre is haunting your future, the spectre
of not having a website.
So, go to wix.com/wisecrack to sign up today.
The only thing you have to lose is your chains.

And as always,
Peace.
